Fig 1 Fig. 2 (a) CO2 conversion, CH3OH selectivity and (b) STY versus GHSV; (c) CO2 conversion, CH3OH selectivity and (d) STY versus temperature. Fig 2 Fig. 3 XRD profiles of (a) ZrO2 with various morphologies and (b) ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts, (c) N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts. Department of Chemical Engineering School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Guizhou University Guiyang Guizhou 550025 China The global carbon dioxide (CO2) emission problem is getting increasingly severe nowadays. Hence a suitable CO2 hydrogenation technology to obtain methanol is an efficient way to achieve carbon neutrality. Zinc oxide (ZnO) nanoparticles were loaded on zirconium dioxide (ZrO2) with different morphologies via the impregnation method. This was followed by the investigation of the effect of zirconia structure and morphology on the interfacial synergy manifested in the catalysts and the catalytic performance in CO2 hydrogenation. The results showed that the CO2 conversion of the ZnO/ZrO2 catalyst possessing a hollow nanoframe-like morphology was significantly enhanced. This catalyst also exhibited the highest methanol space-time yield, which was 1.78 times higher than that of the ZnO/ZrO2 catalyst having an aggregate shape of irregular particles. The unique morphology effectively inhibited the transition of the metastable tetragonal ZrO2 (t-ZrO2) to the monoclinic ZrO2 (m-ZrO2) while forming a special interfacial structure with the loaded ZnO to strengthen the interfacial interaction. This enhanced the hydrogen activation capacity and generated more oxygen vacancies favorable to the activation of CO2. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Morphology effect Zirconia support Oxygen vacancy CO2 hydrogenation Methanol synthesis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The socioeconomic and ecological problems caused by sizeable global carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions have worsened in recent years. It is urgent to solve the problem of CO2 emissions to avoid further damage [1,2]. With the rapid development of the sustainable hydrogen energy sector [3–6], the use of hydrogen to convert CO2 into a range of valuable chemicals holds great promise [7–9]. Among them, methanol is a major raw material and the first objective in the “liquid sunshine” strategy [10]. Through tuning catalysts and the associated reactions, methanol can be further converted into a series of widely used products, such as olefins and aromatics [11–15]. Currently, methanol is mostly produced by gasification and reforming of traditional raw materials [16]. Thus, CO2 hydrogenation to methanol can solve the problem of CO2 emissions while effectively reducing human dependence on non-renewable resources, providing an effective way to achieve carbon neutrality. Catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol are mainly classified into metal-based (Cu-based [17–21], Pd-based [22,23], Pt-based [24], Au-based [25,26], etc.), sulfide-based (MoS2 [27,28], MoS2@C [29]) and metal oxide-based catalysts. Metal-based and sulfide-based catalysts have superior methanol selectivity at ∼180–250°C but are frequently limited by low CO2 conversion. Since CO2 is stable, higher temperatures are more favorable for the activation of CO2. Unfortunately, as the temperature increases, the metal-based catalyst faces a severe reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction and is highly susceptible to sintering and deactivation [30]. Sulfide-based catalysts are subject to excessive hydrogenation to methane at high temperatures, causing a significant reduction in methanol selectivity [28]. Therefore, metal oxide catalysts with superior thermal stability and catalytic performance at higher temperatures stand out. The synergistic effect among the active ingredients in the metal oxides results in high CO2 conversion and high methanol selectivity at ∼300°C [31]. Recently, a series of ZrO2-based MaZrOx catalysts (ZnZrOx [32], GaZrOx [33], CdZrOx [34], etc.) entered the focus. It was found that ZnO, Ga2O3 and CdO have excellent hydrogen dissociation ability, and the coordinatively unsaturated Zr site in ZrO2 is the main site of CO2 adsorption and activation [31,34]. It is also reported that ZrO2 has unique acid-base amphiphilicity, redox properties, weak hydrophilicity, and abundant surface defects [35–37]. Hence, zirconia can be used as an active component, additive, or support. Martin et al. found that by loading In2O3 on m-ZrO2, their strong interaction would produce more oxygen vacancies, achieving 100% methanol selectivity [38]. Xu et al. encapsulated Cu/Zn two-phase on UiO-66-derived ZrO2, which effectively inhibited the buildup of Cu nanoparticles and the separation of Cu/Zn two-phase, showing excellent stability and catalytic performance [39]. In addition, many studies have shown that the crystal shape, morphology, and specific surface area of the catalyst support greatly affect the catalytic performance of the catalyst [32,40–45]. Tian et al. found that catalysts containing mixed crystalline phases of ZrO2 exhibited superior CO2 conversion and olefin yield. This study aimed at modifying the crystal shape of ZrO2 in ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts by Li doping, and it was found that the mixed-crystalline phase of ZrO2 interacts strongly with ZnO and produced more oxygen vacancies [46]. Han et al. used MOF808 to obtain Cu@ZrO2 hollow structures, and found that the hollow morphology of ZrO2 caused the Cu active component to be highly dispersed on the surface and form several Cu-ZrO2 interfaces to achieve improved catalytic performance [47]. Li et al. found that by modulating the morphology of the support in Ni/ZrO2 catalysts, the interaction between the two phases could be enhanced to achieve improved thermal stability and dry reforming of methane [48]. However, the role of the structure and morphology of ZrO2 on the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol is still unclear. This work prepared ZrO2 with hollow nanoframes (ZrO2-F) and ZrO2 with spherical morphology (ZrO2-S) by solvothermal means without surfactant addition. Moreover, the ZrO2 irregular particles (ZrO2-P) were prepared by a simple precipitation method. The ZnO component was loaded on these three ZrO2 supports by impregnation and applied to convert CO2 to methanol via hydrogenation. Research revealed that after the loading of ZnO on ZrO2, the ZrO2-F support effectively inhibited the transformation of the metastable phase t-ZrO2 to m-ZrO2 phase and formed a special interfacial structure with the ZnO phase. The latter produced stronger interfacial interactions and provided abundant oxygen vacancies for CO2 activation. At the same time, the hydrogen activation capacity is promoted by the strengthened electron transfer over the interface. In addition, the morphological tuning of ZrO2 also provides a greater specific surface area and pore capacity, showing a multi-level pore layout. The ZnO/ZrO2-F catalyst exhibited the highest CO2 conversion rate, and its yield of methanol was 1.78 times that of ZnO/ZrO2-P. Its catalytic performance was stable over 100 h without any significant degradation, showing potential industrial application prospects. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of ZrO2 ZrO2 with hollow nanoframes (ZrO2-F) were synthesized based on a procedure reported previously [49]. Zirconocene dichloride (0.2 g) was dissolved in 60 mL acetone and magnetically stirred for 5 min until complete solubilization. Subsequently, 2 mL of ammonia was gradually dropped into the preceding solution. Then, the obtained suspension was transferred to a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was sealed and heated in the oven at 200°C for 12 h. After this, it was allowed to cool down naturally. The product was cleaned by centrifugation with acetone, ethanol, and distilled water. Lastly, the sample was dried at 80°C overnight and calcined at 500°C in static air for 2 h. The preparation of ZrO2 spheres (ZrO2-S) followed the same method as that of ZrO2-F but without the addition of ammonia. ZrO2 irregular particles (ZrO2-P) were prepared by a simple precipitation method. 6.6673 g of Zr(NO3)4·5H2O and 3.283 g of (NH4)2CO3 were each dissolved in 100 mL of deionized water. Then, the (NH4)2CO3 solution was added to the Zr(NO3)4 solution (3 mL∙min−1) with intense stirring at 70°C to form a precipitate. Subsequently, the suspension was stirred at 70°C for 2 h. After natural cooling, it was washed with deionized water and collected by filtration. The product was dried at 110°C for 4 h and calcined at 500°C in static air for 2 h. 2.2 Synthesis of ZnO/ZrO2 ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts were prepared by impregnation method. Zn(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in a certain amount of deionized water and immersed in the ZrO2 supports. Afterward, the samples were kept at room temperature for 24 h and dried at 80°C overnight. Finally, the obtained powder was calcined in air at 500°C for 2 h. The amount of ZnO in all samples was 20 mol%. The catalysts obtained from ZnO impregnated on ZrO2-F, ZrO2-S and ZrO2-P were denoted as ZnO/ZrO2-F, ZnO/ZrO2-S and ZnO/ZrO2-P, respectively (Scheme 1 ). 2.3 Catalyst Evaluation The performance of the prepared catalysts was evaluated in a high-pressure fixed-bed reactor. In general, 0.1 g catalyst (40-80 mesh) was mixed evenly with 0.4 g quartz sand (40-80 mesh) and loaded into the reaction tube. Prior to the reaction, the catalyst was pretreated with 10 V% H2/N2 under predetermined conditions. The reaction was carried out under the following conditions: 3 MPa, 280 to 340°C, V(H2)/V(CO2)=4:1, and gas hourly space velocity (GHSV)=8000 to 32000 mL∙gcat −1∙h−1. The outlet gas temperature was maintained at 200°C and immediately fed to a gas chromatograph (GC, GC2014C, Shimadzu) equipped with flame ionization detector and thermal conductivity detector. For CO2 conversion, product selectivity and methanol space-time yield (STY) were calculated using the following equations: X ( C O 2 ) = ∑ n ( products ) n ( C O 2 ) + ∑ n ( products ) S ( C H 3 OH ) = n ( C H 3 OH ) ∑ n ( products ) S ( CO ) = n ( CO ) ∑ n ( products ) STY ( C H 3 OH ) = GHSV 1000 × 22 . 4 × V % ( C O 2 ) × X ( C O 2 ) × S ( C H 3 OH ) × M C H 3 OH Where n is the concentration of the substance measured by GC multiplied by its carbon number. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst Performance The catalytic performance of the ZnO/ZrO2 catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation was investigated first (Fig. 1 ). Under the same reaction conditions, ZnO/ZrO2-P showed the lowest CO2 conversion (4.1%) and methanol selectivity (63.9%) (Fig. 1a). The catalysts prepared by morphological modulation showed a significant enhancement in performance. ZnO/ZrO2-S exhibited the highest methanol selectivity, 1.24 times that of ZnO/ZrO2-P, although the enhancement of CO2 conversion was not significant. As shown in Fig. 1b, ZnO/ZrO2-F displayed optimal catalytic performance with remarkably enhanced CO2 conversion and methanol STY up to 324 mg∙gcat −1∙h−1, which is 1.78 times that of ZnO/ZrO2-P (comparable to the reported advanced Zr-based catalysts listed in Table S1). The ZnO/ZrO2-F catalyst exhibited excellent stability with an insignificant decrease in CO2 conversion, methanol selectivity and STY up to 100 h (Fig. 1c, d). The catalytic performance of all samples under different reaction conditions is shown in Fig. 2 . The methanol selectivity and STY of three catalysts increased even though CO2 conversion gradually decreased as GHSV varied from 8000 mL∙gcat −1∙h−1 to 32000 mL∙gcat −1∙h−1 (Fig. 2a, b). This suggests that higher GHSV may be more favorable for methanol production. Fig. 2c and 2d display that the CO2 conversion and methanol STY of a series of catalysts increased with the gradual increase in temperature from 280 to 340°C. However, the methanol selectivity of catalysts kept decreasing due to the increased RWGS reaction caused by high temperature. Clearly, ZnO/ZrO2-F had the highest methanol STY and exhibits better catalytic performance regardless of the reaction conditions. 3.2 Characterization of Catalysts The structure of the catalysts was investigated by X-ray diffraction (XRD) before and after impregnation (Fig. 3 a, b). All ZrO2 supports contained the t-ZrO2 and m-ZrO2 crystal phases, as shown by their characteristic diffraction peaks. The diffraction peaks located at 2θ = 17.4°, 24.0°, 28.2°, 31.5°, 34.2°, and 50.1° corresponded to the (011), (110), (-111), (111), (200) and (022) crystal planes of m-ZrO2 (PDF#37-1484), respectively. The reflections identified at 2θ = 30.3°, 35.3°, 50.4°, and 60.2° corresponded to the (011), (110), (112), and (121) crystal planes of t-ZrO2 (PDF#50-1089). Combined with the calculation results of the Scherrer equation (Table S2), the t-ZrO2 and m-ZrO2 crystallite sizes in ZrO2-P support were larger than those of ZrO2-F and ZrO2-S, and the smaller size nanograins were beneficial to provide larger specific surface area. It is worth mentioning that the t-ZrO2 and m-ZrO2 crystallite sizes in the samples before and after ZnO impregnation did not change much. The typical hexagonal ZnO crystalline phase (PDF#36-1451) appeared in all the catalysts (Fig. 3b). The diffraction peaks for (100), (002) and (101) crystal planes of ZnO in ZnO/ZrO2-P were more pronounced at the same ZnO content, which may be related to the inhomogeneous dispersion of ZnO loaded on ZrO2-P [44,50]. It should be noted that the crystalline phase of ZnO/ZrO2-P also changed significantly, with a considerable increase in the intensity of the m-ZrO2 (-111) and (111) crystal planes and a decrease in the intensity of the t-ZrO2 (011) crystal planes, predicting a partial transformation of t-ZrO2 to m-ZrO2 in this sample. A similar trend was observed for ZnO/ZrO2-S. Typically, the t-ZrO2 phase is stable above 1600 K and is considered metastable. By loading ZnO on ZrO2, a transformation to the stable state m-ZrO2 occurs. R. Grabowski and K. Samson found that oxygen vacancies could stabilize t-ZrO2 while studying the impact of ZrO2 crystalline phase structure on the properties of Ag/ZrO2 and Cu/ZrO2 [51]. Meanwhile, calculations showed that oxygen vacancies are more easily formed on t-ZrO2 [52]. It is noteworthy that the crystalline phase of ZrO2-F seemed to be more stable after loading ZnO, and t-ZrO2 was still the main crystalline phase in ZnO/ZrO2-F. The relative phase compositions of t-ZrO2 and m-ZrO2 in different samples before and after impregnation were derived by the Rietveld method (Table S2). After impregnation with ZnO, the t-ZrO2 phase content in each catalyst was reduced to different degrees. Among them, the t-ZrO2 content in ZnO/ZrO2-P decreased the most significantly. In contrast, the t-ZrO2 content in ZnO/ZrO2-F had the least decreasing trend and t-ZrO2 remained its main crystalline phase, confirming the phase transition trend discussed above. Evidently, ZrO2-F with special structural morphology can effectively inhibit the transformation of the metastable phase t-ZrO2 to m-ZrO2 phase. This may be associated with more oxygen vacancies on the surface of ZnO/ZrO2-F. Combined with the catalytic performance, it can be deduced that the content of t-ZrO2 phase in the catalyst was positively correlated with its catalytic performance. Fig. 3c shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms for different catalysts. All were type IV isotherms, indicating the mesoporous nature of the materials. ZnO/ZrO2-P and ZnO/ZrO2-S showed an H2-type hysteresis loop, typical for ink bottle types of mesopores. In contrast, ZnO/ZrO2-F shows an H3-type hysteresis loop at a higher and wider relative pressure range, indicating a slightly larger mesopore size and a multistage pore distribution (Fig. S1). From the catalyst pore structure parameters (Table S3), the specific surface areas of the ZrO2-F, ZrO2-S and ZrO2-P supports were estimated to be 70.6, 50.9 and 31.1 m2∙g−1, respectively. The specific surface area and pore volume of all three catalysts decreased after ZnO loading. The specific surface area of the ZnO/ZrO2-F catalyst was 2.41 times that of ZnO/ZrO2-P, while the pore capacity was 7.67 times higher. The reaction usually occurs at the active sites on the surface for loaded catalysts. Greater specific surface area means additional active sites to promote overall catalytic performance [32]. The excellent pore capacity and unique multi-level pore distribution benefit the mass transfer process [53]. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) micrographs of the catalysts are displayed in Fig. 4 . The ZrO2-P irregular particles were produced by the precipitation method. At the same time, ZrO2-F with hollow nanoframe-like morphology (Figs. 4c and S2a) and ZrO2-S with spherical morphology (Figs. 4e and S2b) were successfully modified by solvothermal means. It is worth mentioning that the morphology of the three catalysts before and after impregnation was stable and essentially unchanged (Fig. 4a-f). High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) micrographs of the ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts are shown in Figs. 4g and S3. The ZnO (100), m-ZrO2 (-111), and t-ZrO2 (011) lattice fringe spacings appeared in all three catalysts, indicating good crystallinity, which was in agreement with the XRD results. To be noted, there was a distinct interface between the three phases in the ZnO/ZrO2-F catalyst (Fig. 4g). It was speculated that the formation of this particular interfacial structure will contribute to the strong interaction among metal oxides between the three phases. However, this was not found in the ZnO/ZrO2-S and ZnO/ZrO2-P samples (Fig. S3). In addition, the ZnO/ZrO2-F catalysts had a uniform distribution of Zn, Zr, and O elements (Fig. 4h), indicating that ZnO was highly dispersed on ZrO2-F and there was a distinct mesoporous structure (Fig. S4). The structural properties of different catalysts were investigated using Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 5 ). The characteristic peaks at 144, 269 and 317 cm−1 belong to the vibrational modes of t-ZrO2 (Raman-active modes of B1g and Eg) [54], and 178, 189, 222, 308, 333, 346, 381, 476, 510, 538, 561 and 612 cm−1 are attributed to the vibrational modes of m-ZrO2 (Raman-active modes of Ag and Bg) [55]. The peak at 99 and 437 cm−1 belong to the active vibration modes of the hexagonal ZnO (Raman-active modes of E2 low and E2 high) [56]. Clearly, the content of t-ZrO2 in ZnO/ZrO2-F was significantly higher compared to ZrO2-P and ZrO2-S, agreeing with the XRD results. Typically, the Raman signal at 632 cm−1 corresponds to asymmetric vibration of the oxygen vacancies in the catalysts [57,58]. Visibly, the ZnO/ZrO2-F catalyst possessed the highest content of oxygen vacancy. The surface chemistry of Zn and Zr species was studied by X-ray photoelectron spectrometry (XPS). The Zn 2p spectrum of pure ZnO showed two characteristic signals situated at 1021.1 and 1044.1 eV, which belonged to Zn2+ (Zn 2p3/2 and Zn 2p1/2) (Fig. 6 a) [59]. After ZnO impregnation on the ZrO2, the binding energies of Zn 2p in ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts were all shifted to larger values by 0.5∼0.8 eV. Compared with the other two catalysts, Zn 2p showed higher binding energy in ZnO/ZrO2-F. Moreover, the loading of ZnO promoted the reduction of Zr 3d binding energy in the composite oxide (Fig. 6b), indicating that ZrO2 can accept the electrons transferred from ZnO [60], thus enhancing the interaction between ZnO and ZrO2. In addition, significant Zr 3d binding energy shifts were found on ZnO/ZrO2-F. This can be attributed to the special interfacial structure formed on ZnO/ZrO2-F, resulting in a higher electron density between the three phases in the catalyst, producing strong metal oxide interactions. O 1s spectra were used to further investigate the oxygen vacancy concentration on the surface of various ZrO2 and ZnO/ZrO2. Typically, the peak in the range of 529.5 to 530.5 eV is from lattice oxygen (OL). In comparison, the 530.5 to 531.5 eV signal belongs to oxygen atoms next to oxygen vacancies near the surface (OV). The 531.5 to 532.5 eV peak corresponds to hydroxyl oxygen (OOH) [61–63]. The relative concentration of oxygen vacancy (OV) was measured by the peak amounts of the various oxygen types: OV/(OL+OV+OOH). The ZrO2-F support exhibited the largest relative oxygen vacancy concentration of 24.81% among the supports (Fig. S5). Table S4 gives the electron binding energies of O 1s orbitals in different environments and the occupancy ratio. It was found that (Fig. 6c and Table S4) ZnO/ZrO2-F has the highest relative oxygen vacancy concentration of 35.83%, indicating that the special interfacial structure formed after ZnO impregnation further enriched the oxygen defect concentration. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) was used to estimate the relative concentration of oxygen vacancies due to its sensitivity to unpaired electrons captured in oxygen vacancies [64]. The signal at g = 2.002∼2.004 generally belongs to oxygen vacancies [61,64,65]. ZnO/ZrO2-F catalyst displayed the strongest EPR signal (Fig. 6d), consistent with the XPS O 1s spectrum and Raman spectroscopy results. These results demonstrate that the particular interfacial structure formed in ZnO/ZrO2-F enhanced the interaction between the three phases in the catalyst and generated more oxygen vacancies, thus promoting CO2 adsorption and activation. To reveal the interaction between ZnO and ZrO2, temperature-programmed desorption of the preabsorbed H2 (H2-TPD) or CO2 (CO2-TPD) were performed on the catalysts. In the CO2-TPD pattern (Figs. 7 a and S6a), all ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts exhibited two CO2 desorption peaks, corresponding to weakly (<300°C) and strongly (>300°C) basic sites. However, there was no desorption peak in the case of pure ZnO at the weak adsorption site. The intensity of the weak desorption peak of ZrO2-F was remarkably stronger than ZrO2-P, which might be associated with the specific surface area values and amount of oxygen vacancies. Notably, the enhancement of the CO2 adsorption capacity of ZnO/ZrO2-F was most obvious at the weakly basic sites, which may be related to the creation of new active sites. There was a clear difference in CO2 desorption capacity between the catalysts as follows: ZnO/ZrO2-F (100) > ZnO/ZrO2-S (80) > ZnO/ZrO2-P (58) (Fig. 7b). This indicates that stronger Zn-O-Zr interfacial interactions were generated on ZnO/ZrO2-F, and thus more oxygen vacancies were obtained. This also coincides with the results from the catalytic performance, XPS, Raman, and EPR analyses. Fig. 7c shows the H2-TPD of the series ZnO/ZrO2 with two desorption peaks at lower (<300°C) and higher (>300°C) temperatures over the catalysts. The H2 adsorption capacity of ZnO/ZrO2-P was the weakest at either of the desorption peak positions. In addition, taking ZnO/ZrO2-F as an example, Fig. S6b shows the H2-TPD spectra of the catalyst before and after impregnation. At the low-temperature desorption peak, ZnO/ZrO2-F had a larger desorption peak area, indicating that the interaction between ZnO and ZrO2-F enhanced the hydrogen activation capacity of the catalyst. As seen from Fig. 7d, the order of H2 desorption capacity was ZnO/ZrO2-S (100) > ZnO/ZrO2-F (92) > ZnO/ZrO2-P (64), which is concordant with the order of methanol selectivity of each catalyst. Combining multiple characterization results, it was found that ZnO/ZrO2-F with hollow nano-framework morphology exhibited a more stable t-ZrO2 phase structure than the other two catalysts. Its unique interfacial structure enhanced the interaction between ZnO and ZrO2-F, strengthened the hydrogen activation ability, generated more oxygen vacancies, and promoted the adsorption ability and activation of ZnO/ZrO2-F on H2 and CO2, which in turn improved the catalytic activity. 3.3 Reaction Mechanism The reaction intermediates that exist on the surface of the ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts was studied via In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFT) to reveal the reaction mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation (Fig. 8 ). The bands at 1370, 1381, 1582, 2879 and 2973 cm−1 can be attributed to formate species (HCOO*) [66–68]. The signals at 1051, 2827 and 2937 cm−1 are assigned to methoxy species (CH3O*) [64,69–71]. The peak at 1510 cm−1 belongs to carbonate species (CO3 2-) [72]. The three ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts showed the same intermediates under the same reaction conditions, indicating that the synthesis of methanol followed the carbonate-formate-methoxy pathway in all the cases (Fig. 9 ). The methoxy-related bands appearing within the first 5 min of the reaction were not evident (at 1051, 2827 and 2937 cm−1). Those signals at 2827 and 2937 cm−1 gradually became stronger with increase in reaction time (Fig. S7), indicating that the stepwise hydrogenation of formate resulted in the methoxy species. It is worth mentioning that the intensity of the characteristic signals of each reaction intermediate on the ZnO/ZrO2-F catalyst was significantly higher than other catalysts during the process. To evaluate the concentration of reaction intermediates for each catalyst, the in situ DRIFTS spectra of each catalyst (at 60 min of reaction) were compared. As seen from Fig. 8d, the reaction intermediate concentrations of various ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts were consistent with their relative oxygen vacancy concentrations in the order of ZnO/ZrO2-F > ZnO/ZrO2-S > ZnO/ZrO2-P (this order was also consistent with the catalytic efficiency sequence). 4 Conclusions In summary, ZrO2 supports with different morphologies were prepared by solvothermal and precipitation methods in this study, and the effects of the structure and morphology of ZrO2 support on the catalytic performance of ZnO/ZrO2 in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol were investigated. Based on the tuned preparation of the original bimetallic oxide catalysts [31,32,46,65,73] with supplemented morphological engineering strategies, the hollow-nanoframed-ZnO/ZrO2-F catalysts were obtained with large specific surface area, strong metal oxide interactions, and abundant oxygen vacancies. The formation of oxygen vacancies facilitates the stabilization of the metastable t-ZrO2 phase, and the oxygen vacancies are important active sites in the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. It was found that ZrO2-F with hollow nano-framework morphology effectively stabilized the metastable t-ZrO2 phase after impregnation with ZnO. The unique interfacial structure between ZnO and ZrO2-F further enhanced the interaction between them to enhance hydrogen activation and generate more oxygen vacancies for the adsorption of activated CO2. The ZnO/ZrO2-F catalyst exhibited high CO2 conversion and its methanol space-time yield was 1.78 times higher than that of ZnO/ZrO2-P which has an aggregate shape of irregular particles. In situ DRIFTS results showed that ZnO/ZrO2-F with special structural morphology produced more methanol intermediates under the same reaction conditions, thus increasing the methanol yield. These results confirm the essential role played by the morphological engineering of catalyst supports in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, which can provide new research ideas for the structural design of loaded catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The global carbon dioxide (CO2) emission problem is getting increasingly severe nowadays. Hence a suitable CO2 hydrogenation technology to obtain methanol is an efficient way to achieve carbon neutrality. Zinc oxide (ZnO) nanoparticles were loaded on zirconium dioxide (ZrO2) with different morphologies via the impregnation method. This was followed by the investigation of the effect of zirconia structure and morphology on the interfacial synergy manifested in the catalysts and the catalytic performance in CO2 hydrogenation. The results showed that the CO2 conversion of the ZnO/ZrO2 catalyst possessing a hollow nanoframe-like morphology was significantly enhanced. This catalyst also exhibited the highest methanol space-time yield, which was 1.78 times higher than that of the ZnO/ZrO2 catalyst having an aggregate shape of irregular particles. The unique morphology effectively inhibited the transition of the metastable tetragonal ZrO2 (t-ZrO2) to the monoclinic ZrO2 (m-ZrO2) while forming a special interfacial structure with the loaded ZnO to strengthen the interfacial interaction. This enhanced the hydrogen activation capacity and generated more oxygen vacancies favorable to the activation of CO2.
coredata.dc:title: Role of the structure and morphology of zirconia in ZnO/ZrO2 catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol
